description: From Middle English ragge, from Old English ragg (suggested by derivative raggiġ (“shaggy; bristly; ragged”)), from Old Norse rǫgg (“tuft; shagginess”), from Proto-Germanic *rawwa-, probably related to *rūhaz. Cognate with Swedish ragg. Related to rug.

entries.meaning: (in the plural) Tattered clothes.
A piece of old cloth, especially one used for cleaning, patching, etc.; a tattered piece of cloth; a shred or tatter.
A shabby, beggarly fellow; a ragamuffin.
A ragged edge in metalworking.
(nautical, slang) A sail, or any piece of canvas.
(singular or plural, slang) Sanitary napkins, pads, or other materials used to absorb menstrual discharge.
(slang, derogatory) A newspaper or magazine, especially one whose journalism is considered to be of poor quality.
(poker) A poor, low-ranking kicker.
examples: I have ace-four on my hand. In other words, I have ace-rag.

entries.meaning: (slang, theater) A curtain of various kinds.
(dated) A person suffering from exhaustion or lack of energy.

verbs.description: rag (third-person singular simple present rags, present participle ragging, simple past and past participle ragged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To decorate (a wall, etc.) by applying paint with a rag.
(intransitive) To become tattered.

description: Unknown origin; perhaps the same word as Etymology 1, above.

entries.meaning: A coarse kind of rock, somewhat cellular in texture; ragstone.
examples: the three walls around the garden, each one of thirty-three feet, were built out of three layers of stone — pebble stone, flint and rag stone.

verbs.description: rag (third-person singular simple present rags, present participle ragging, simple past and past participle ragged)

entries.meaning: To break (ore) into lumps for sorting.
To cut or dress roughly, as a grindstone.
(dated) A prank or practical joke.
(UK, Ireland) A society run by university students for the purpose of charitable fundraising.

verbs.description: rag (third-person singular simple present rags, present participle ragging, simple past and past participle ragged)

entries.meaning: To scold or tell off; to torment; to banter.
(Britain slang) To drive a car or another vehicle in a hard, fast or unsympathetic manner.
To tease or torment, especially at a university; to bully, to haze.

description: Perhaps from ragged. Compare later ragtime.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, US) An informal dance party featuring music played by African-American string bands. [19th c.]
A ragtime song, dance or piece of music. [from 19th c.]

verbs.description: rag (third-person singular simple present rags, present participle ragging, simple past and past participle ragged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To play or compose (a piece, melody, etc.) in syncopated time.
(intransitive, informal) To dance to ragtime music.
(music, obsolete) To add syncopation (to a tune) and thereby make it appropriate for a ragtime song.
